references:
As demonstrated in Table 1, RosePO-h surpasses all baseline methods (including conventional recommendation models and LLM4Rec works) across three datasets in terms of the evaluation metrics HR@1, HR@5, HR@10, NDCG@5, and NDCG@10.
This result highlights the exceptional efficacy of our proposed method.
Notably, the preference alignment stage exhibits improvements over two of its prior checkpoints (i.e., PT and SFT).
Specifically, the relative enhancements of RosePO-h over SFT on the metric HR@1 are 8.11%, 4.51%, and 4.25% for the Movielens, Goodreads, and Steam datasets, respectively.
This indicates that we addressed the inherent defects of the models in earlier stages, thereby enhancing the accuracy (i.e., helpfulness) of the recommendations.

S4.T2.caption: Table 2. Optimization Objectives for Preference Alignment.
references: We select DPO and its variants to serve as additional baselines for comparison. We have: (1) DPO (Rafailov et al., 2023): offers a closed-form solution of the reward model in RLHF and optimizes the preference model offline. (2) (Rafailov et al., 2023): offers a closed-form solution of the reward model in RLHF and optimizes the preference model offline. (2) IPO (Azar et al., 2024): derives a general objective to bypass two approximations in DPO. (3) (Azar et al., 2024): derives a general objective to bypass two approximations in DPO. (3) Conservative DPO (cDPO) (Mitchell, 2023): introduces a hyperparameter (Mitchell, 2023): introduces a hyperparameter ϵ italic-ϵ \epsilon italic_ϵ to model flip rate of noisy labels. (4) ϵ italic-ϵ \epsilon italic_ϵ ϵ ϵ italic-ϵ italic-ϵ italic-ϵ\epsilon \epsilonitalic_ϵ italic_ϵ to model flip rate of noisy labels. (4) Robust DPO (rDPO) (Chowdhury et al., 2024): designs an unbiased estimate of the original Binary Cross Entropy loss. (5) (Chowdhury et al., 2024): designs an unbiased estimate of the original Binary Cross Entropy loss. (5) RPO (Pang et al., 2024): includes a negative log-likelihood (NLL) loss term for the paired chose responses. (6) (Pang et al., 2024): includes a negative log-likelihood (NLL) loss term for the paired chose responses. (6) CPO (Xu et al., 2024): employs sequence likelihood as a reward and trains jointly with an SFT objective. (7) (Xu et al., 2024): employs sequence likelihood as a reward and trains jointly with an SFT objective. (7) SimPO (Meng et al., 2024): utilizes the average log probability of a sequence as a reward to eliminate the need for a reference model, and introduces a target reward margin between the chosen and rejected responses. (8) (Meng et al., 2024): utilizes the average log probability of a sequence as a reward to eliminate the need for a reference model, and introduces a target reward margin between the chosen and rejected responses. (8) Softmax DPO (S-DPO) (Chen et al., 2024): introduces DPO into LLM4Rec by randomly sampling multiple negative items as rejected responses, to enhance the accuracy of recommendation. (Chen et al., 2024): introduces DPO into LLM4Rec by randomly sampling multiple negative items as rejected responses, to enhance the accuracy of recommendation. 7 77 77We adapt S-DPO to the task setting of ranking item candidates, keeping the same implementation (including prompts and training) as ours, except for the softmax loss. Detailed objective formulations are listed in Table 2.

88For Goodreads, IPO maintains anomalous gradients under various hyperparameters. for objectives are presented in Table 3.
It shows that RosePO surpasses the baselines across all five evaluation metrics on both Goodreads and Steam datasets.
In the case of the Movielens dataset, our method focuses on the fine-grained ranking of candidate items, rendering the HR@1, NDCG@5, and NDCG@10 metrics more crucial.
Thus, in these three metrics, our approach consistently outperforms the baselines on Movielens dataset.
In the context of Movielens, our method prioritizes the fine-grained ranking of candidate items, thus making the HR@1, NDCG@5, and NDCG@10 metrics of paramount importance. Our approach consistently surpasses the baselines across these three metrics.

references:
As shown in Table 4, RosePO-h (self-hard sampling) surpasses all other sampling strategies, particularly uniform sampling.
This highlights the significant advantage of the self-hard sampling approach in enhancing recommendation performance.
Other sampling strategies, such as uniform, semantic, and popular sampling, maintain comparable performance levels with the previous SFT model.

In order to examine the effectiveness of RosePO-s in mitigating semantic hallucination while achieving the performance displayed in Table 4, we first need to quantify semantic hallucination.
We expect that the semantic similarity between the recommended items and the user’s historical sequence will maintain a comparable similarity to the actual subsequent items that the user has interacted with.
Therefore, we define the semantic bias for the recommendation item <math alttext="i_{k}" class="ltx_Math" display="inline" id="S4.SS5.SSS1.p1.1.m1.1">

Dataset MovieLens Goodreads Steam

references:
(2) Data scale.
Due to limited computational resources, we conduct experiments only on relatively small-scale datasets (cf. Table 6).
Nonetheless, it requires approximately 24 A800 GPU hours of training for the complete preference dataset.
Additionally, we investigate the impact of varying quantities of preference data on the recommendation performance in Appendix D.
To scale up to larger datasets, future work should explore improvements on efficiency.

references:
Results.
We can observe from Table 7 that RosePO-h not only outperforms all the baselines but also improves the recommendation performance of the previous stage (SFT model).
This demonstrates that, when compared to other methods focusing on helpful recommendations, our RosePO-h method exhibits superior advantages.
